item.title: Watch This Ridiculous 70-person Super Mario 64 Relay
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

This year marks the 30th anniversary of Super Mario 64, a game that was designed to be a single-player showcase for the Nintendo 64. This title may not have been built with multiplayer in mind, but at this year's Awesome Games Done Quick (AGDQ) charity livestream, players turned Super Mario 64 into a team sport as 70 different speedrunners joined forces for a single 70-star run through the game.

It was clear pretty early on that all of the speedrunners knew the tricks to getting Super Mario 64's stars in as little time as possible. Under their collective control, Mario pulled off some of the most athletic moves we've seen from Nintendo's iconic plumber. They even made some of the game's trickiest platforming moments seem easy.

In total, this speed run lasted just under two hours. There are 120 stars in the game, so it's possible to pull off an even larger Super Mario 64 relay at future AGDQ events. The current AGDQ event also had a Mario Kart World speedrunner complete the All ? Panels category in under 30 minutes.

During the last few years, Super Mario 64 players have pulled off an "impossible" 1-Up trick and opened an in-game door that was sealed for decades. An adventurous modder even brought Minecraft into Super Mario 64 with a hack that works on the physical N64 game as well.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Sims Project Rene Has Shifted Into A Mobile Multiplayer Game
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The next game in The Sims franchise--codenamed Project Rene--has turned into a mobile-first experience that's all about social multiplayer. It is not The Sims 5, and developer Maxis states this title can live in harmony with The Sims 4 and any future single-player installments in the series.

EA and Maxis discussed the future of The Sims in a blog post celebrating the new year. Within this article, the companies noted that "Project Rene has evolved to focus on social multiplayer play, offering a more direct way for friends to share creativity together." In addition, the "mobile-first life-sim game" is about collaboration.

However, The Sims franchise won't forget about its roots. The blog post states: "At its core, The Sims was built on a deep, single-player life simulation, chock full of rich systems, meaningful storytelling, and player agency that puts you in control. That foundation isn't going anywhere."

Originally announced in 2022, Project Rene was presumed to be The Sims 5. But that changed in recent years, as EA and Maxis pointed out the in-development game would complement The Sims 4 instead of replacing it. Earlier this month, The Sims team declared their values wouldn't change, in wake of fan concerns regarding EA's $55 billion deal with the Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund affecting the life-sim series.

Talk of Project Rene exploring multiplayer concepts emerged in 2023, with Animal Crossing and Among Us name-checked as possible inspirations. Now, it's clear, Project Rene is going all in on social multiplayer. Outside of gaming, there is also a Sims movie in the works.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
